text: (upbeat music)
- Hi, everyone.
Welcome.
Today we have two amazing co-founders,
Jhanvi and Ketaki talking about Krikey AI.
Jhanvi, Ketaki, welcome.
Really excited to have you here.
Can you tell us a little bit about Krikey
and how you got started?
- Thank you so much for having us
both to you Swami and to AWS.
We're really excited to be here
and share more about our startup journey.

We are Krikey AI an AI
animation tools company
and we have a foundation model for video
to 3D character animation.

So you can upload a video for
example, of someone dancing

and we convert that to
3D character animation
in less than five minutes.
Around our foundation model,

we've built a video editor
tool that enables you

to add lip sync dialogue
in over 20 languages,
which is powered by Amazon Polly,

AI generated scenes or
backgrounds, facial expressions,

hand gestures and more to
create an animated video
or FBX file that you can export
to build out your video game.

We're really excited to be a
part of the Amazon ecosystem
and we're also a part of

the AWS Generative AI
Accelerator program last year.
- Wow. Wow.
Sounds like an awesome, I mean use case.
So what made you focus on this area
and then how you got started there?

- Yes, so we are actually
going into our seventh year
at the startup.
So we started as a small game studio.

So we produced mobile games
and augmented reality games.
We built games for different brands,
but our biggest bottleneck
as a small game studio was animation.
We only had one animator
and sometimes it would take a couple weeks
to get a new animation for our game.

And so we realized we
needed to find a solution
first for ourselves.
But when we built our AI animation tool,
we realized it had such tremendous power
to create a new market.

There's so many people today
who don't know how to animate

but would like to so that
they can use these animations
if you're a teacher in a lesson plan,

students in book reports,
social media and marketing teams

to be able to use talking
animated characters

in their social media
and marketing campaigns.

So there's so many use cases
that we started to see.

So we ended up pivoting
our business two years ago
to just focus on AI animation tools
and bring those to market

so people in all verticals
from gaming to media
and entertainment to sports leagues

to education can actually start
to produce animated content
on their own.
We were lucky, we were selected a year ago

to be in the AWS Generative
AI Accelerator program.
We were a part of the first cohort

and that again, completely
transformed our business
and what we believed was possible.

And so we're so excited to
be here today still working
very closely with Amazon.

In the year that we've
been working with them

after the Accelerator, we
were able to do a partnership

with Canva, the design company
and also Adobe Express.

So a version of our AI
animation tool is available
inside of both of those design tools.

And we also just recently
launched our enterprise product
on the AWS marketplace.

- Wow, those are like
great milestones already

in terms of what you're
able to accomplish.
Congratulations.
You covered a lot of things.

I'm just going to double click
and unpack on a few things.
You mentioned you are actually building
your own foundational model to take video

to produce 3D animation
and also leveraging

Gen AI for like text
to speech and so forth,
essentially to build like an animation

video or gaming output or
any of these workloads.

So what are some of the core
things you're using Gen AI for?
Can you just double click on it?
Are you like training your own models
or leveraging off the shelf or so forth?
- Yeah, absolutely.

So the core of our product
is video to animation,
which is our own foundation model
that we've trained ourselves

and that's been trained
against video data inputs.

And some animation inputs
as Jhanvi mentioned,
we used to be a game studio,
so we did have quite a lot of animations
that we could use in our training dataset.

And then we've also commercially
licensed some video content
as well to train on.

And the way it works is when
somebody uploads a video
to our platform, we can actually find

all of the animatable
humans in a given video,
or I should say bipedal characters.

It doesn't have to be a
human but any character
that walks on two legs we can animate

and once we see that
character in the video,
we can attach the skeleton to it
and extract the motion vectors.

So basically taking 2D
motion vectors from a video
and then transposing them into 3D space.
So that Krikey has built all on our own

and that's really the
core focus of our product.

We do have a number of
other Gen AI offerings
inside of our tool.

For example, we use Amazon
Polly to generate AI voices.

So of course once you've
animated a character,

the next step is to bring
it to life with speech.

We have our own lip-syncing
solution for the characters,
but the voice of the character
is actually powered by Amazon Polly.
So people can write their own script
and then they can choose whatever language
they'd like for their characters.
And something very exciting about our tool

is before Krikey AI, if
you wanted to produce
animated content, well first of all,
you had to be very technical to do so,
required a lot of training,

you know, many years of
knowledge, but more importantly,
every time you wanted your character
to speak in a different language,

you would actually have
to redo the lip sync
so that the character would look as though
it was speaking this new language.
With our tool that's all instantaneous.
So whatever language you choose,
an accent and dialogue from Amazon Polly,

our characters can
immediately lip sync to that.
So it really cuts down the time required

to produce animated content
across many different languages.
- Nice.

And when it comes to building
the foundational models

I'm just curious, I mean
lot involves in training

these models and also getting
the right data and annotation.
So what kind of tools are you using
and are these on the AWS tools

or can you share more on
like the core platform
that it is based on.
- Yeah, yeah, absolutely.
So Krikey is built exclusively on AWS

and in the beginning we were
starting to train our model

this is actually also related
to the AWS Gen AI Accelerator.
We had no idea that we could work with AWS
to label our data.

We're a very small team, you
know, less than 20 people,
and we were actually manually labeling
all of our video data points ourselves.

As you can imagine, this
is a huge undertaking.

It took up a lot of the
team's time and effort.
And then when we were in the accelerator,
we found out about SageMaker Ground Truth

and we realized that we
could actually partner

with their team to have
them help us label our data.

And it's been an incredible
experience working with them.

They've actually labeled all
of the data that has been used
to train the Krikey foundation model

and we work with them to provide
them a set of guidelines.

So what types of phrases
or words are we looking for
in these labels.

And they actually built
us a custom interface

for video labeling to
ensure that we could get
the highest quality labels
and that saved us thousands of hours.

We now don't have to label
our data ourselves anymore

and we can't believe that
we were ever doing that

because we didn't know about
SageMaker Ground truth.

But it's been an amazing
partnership with them.
- That's awesome.
That's actually a great story to tell

and some of the undifferentiated
heavy lifting we can remove
from your hands.
Well now as an user of Krikey,
like how are your employees

or customers benefiting
from use of like Krikey
and Gen AI in general?

Just trying to get a sense
on what is possible now
that wasn't before.

- Yes, our team loves using
the tools that we have

to make sure people are not
just making videos all day.
But it's great that our team loves it.

We are our own first customer,
which is really important

because a lot of love goes
into building the tool,
adding new features.
What I think has been most exciting for us

is that we feel like we
are creating a new market.
We have consumers coming to our tool

who've never even thought
of animating before,

but it suddenly becomes a
core part of their business.

We have one small game
studio who we are doing

a case study with now
they build games for Alexa
and before they had our tool,
they were hand drawing the animations
and trying to make GIFs out of them.

Now they can actually
animate this character,
they can also make it talk

and they can do all this
within a few minutes

and it just has completely
transformed their ability

to build games, bring them to
market, actually publish them

and even iterate on
the game to improve it.
And then I think that is one example
of a really powerful story where this tool
has enabled a business to exist.
We also have lots of teachers that come in
to make lesson plans

with animated characters
talking in different languages.

Students, we've had a
student do a video resume
with an animated version of themselves

explaining to a company why
they want an internship.
So these are some small specific examples.

On the university front we
have a VR lab that is using it
to animate characters
for immersive experiences and research.
They have a team of PhD students,
none of whom are animators,
but they all need to build VR experiences
for their research projects
and they need animated characters.

So they use our tool to
animate the characters
for their VR research.
There's another teacher, a professor

who is a dance professor and
she teaches West African dance
and she is using animation as a new medium
to teach in her classroom.

These are all people who
before encountering Krikey AI
did not know how to animate,

maybe didn't have the
time or the resources
to learn how to animate,

but now can incorporate
animation into the core

of what they do and what
they're passionate about.
- That's awesome.
Actually, so much of the phrases

what you use is very similar
to how we talk about AWS
or many of our services on being able

to accelerate productivity,
especially for folks
who don't have the time or the skills.

It's fascinating what you
all are doing on this front.
So it's the primary set of use cases

all around like folks who
like game studio producers

or are there more
verticals to your envision?
- So we sort of see it as two verticals.
So there's the consumer vertical
and then the enterprise vertical.
On the consumer front,

anybody can come to our
website at Krikey.ai
and anybody can use the tool
to animate a talking 3D character.
So we have a pretty robust free version
and then a subscription model as well.

And that is where we get
the teachers, the students,

the individual marketing
and social media teams.
They come to our website.

Our enterprise tool is
intended for universities,

game studios, film studios
that are looking to optimize

or accelerate their creative
production workflow.

Some of these companies
have large video archives

that they wanna convert to
animation for use in a video game
or for use with fan engagement.
And so this tool enables them to do that
in a very efficient way

at lower cost than they
would say if they needed

to use a motion capture
studio where they have to hire

the studio, the actor,
the suit, the cameras,
it's a lot more expensive.

One way that some of
our enterprise customers

view our tool is
markerless motion capture.

So a lower cost solution to
convert video, for example,
sports footage to animation very quickly
so they can use it in their end product.
- That's awesome.

Where are you hoping
to go next with Gen AI?
- Our goal is to enable anybody
to animated talking 3D character
and to bring our workflow into every
creative production pipeline from media
to entertainment, gaming and sports.
- That's awesome.

And do you feel like that
in terms of technology

being what it's capable of,
you expect that to happen
over the period of like next year or two?

- I hope it's a year or
two, but I'll tag Ketaki in
to share her technical view of this.
- Yeah definitely.
I think, so on the technical side,

we usually retrain our
model every few months
with new data points.
And I think our goal as Jhanvi said,
is to really empower anyone
to get high fidelity animations
regardless of their skill level.
So part of that is the technical side
of the foundation model,

but I would say actually
the other side of it
is how easy is our tool to use,

you know, how intuitive is
it for somebody who knows
nothing about technology to come in
and in less than 60 seconds
be able to animate a talking avatar?

And so while we are always
focused on, you know,

retraining our model and
improving the fidelity
and the quality of the animations,

I would say we're equally
focused on the user experience
and especially the onboarding

and how easy can we make
this for pretty much anyone

to come in and build
an animated experience.
- That's awesome.
I'm go actually this conversation just,

it's inspired me to get
my 9-year-old daughter
to go try Krikey.

I'm gonna have her go try
and see what she does.
Anyway, I wanna jump into the last one,
which is something I ask all innovators
who are leading the way in Gen AI

and experimenting with
a lot of new use cases.

For all others who are
interested in getting started
or further innovating using generative AI,

what are the set of top two or
three advices you would give?

- I think our top advice for
companies experimenting with

or thinking about getting into
generative AI is to just try,

the first step is to try, we
never know what's possible

until we make an effort
to try even for ourselves.
During the process of building this,
we had to do a business pivot,
which is a very difficult thing to do
after being a game studio for five years.

There was no precedent for
what we wanted to achieve.

We had a vision and we didn't
succeed at every attempt,

but we kept trying because
we knew that this was,

there was a need in the market
for what we wanted to build

and we knew there was a greater
market out there of people

that would access and want to
use this tool if it existed.
So my top advice is just to keep trying
and experimenting, trying different tools,

different methodologies
for what you're building.

- Yeah, and I think I
would follow up on that

and say a very important
part of our journey

as a startup was the
AWS Gen AI Accelerator.

It added so much value for
us as a really small team
and has totally accelerated our business.

We didn't even know that we
could have an enterprise product
before we were in the Gen AI Accelerator,
which is kind of funny to think about now,
but at the time we were just so focused on
building a consumer offering

and we had no clue that
enterprises might be interested
in something we were building.
And so I think applying to that program

or programs like it throughout
the AWS organization

are really important,
especially for a small business
'cause there's always so much to learn

and there's so many
resources inside of AWS,
both technical and go-to-market resources

that can be used to help
improve your business.
- And I'll say a third one,

which is if you're a
startup, build on AWS,
there's no better place to go.

The team at AWS has
been so supportive of us

on every front from
technical to go-to market

and as a small team that
mentorship and guidance

and actual concrete support
means the world to us.

And I think for every startup
as you're thinking about
where to start building, go to AWS first.

- That is, I mean, such
a nice thing to say,
but really glad you are having
such a positive experience as well.
And your set of advice is thank you.

And your set of advice
is on like experimenting
and constantly innovating
and pivoting is, I mean, a really,
a great piece of feedback.
And it's amazing to see you rethinking
your own entire business using Gen AI.
Such an inspiring journey.
I mean journey from you both.
Thanks again for all the amazing insights
and the conversation.

I really enjoyed it and
wishing you, I mean,
continued success in your journey as well.
Thank you.
- Thank you.
Thank you so much for having us.
